node.text:
🍣 SUSHI WITH KIDS // Before you scroll past this post, because you think making sushi with your kids is too hard, STOP! 🛑 Let me tell you, it is totally doable and the results are deeelicious! 🤩 We used @gimmegrams sushi nori, which is restaurant-quality and organic! 🤤 Just watch the full video 📹 to see my 3 year old in action, and read on below👇 for the step-by-step instructions and some tips to make things as easy as possible! 🙌
-
💚 Sponsored 💚 
-
HERE’S WHAT YOU NEED
• 2 cups sushi rice cooked, we made ours in an instant pot!
• Rice Vinegar
• Sugar
• Salt
• gimMe Sushi Nori
• Sesame Seed
• Avocado
• Cucumber
• Imitation Crab
-
HOW TO
(1) Season the sushi rice to taste, we added about 1/4 cup vinegar, 1/2 tsp sugar, and 1 tsp salt;
(2) On top of a rolling mat, place one sheet of gimMe Sushi Nori (rough side up!);
(3) Spread the sushi rice on top in an even layer. (Wet your hands as needed!)
(4) Sprinkle sesame seeds on top of the rice;
(5) Flip the rice-covered nori over;
(6) On top of the nori, arrange slices of avocado, slices of cucumber, and imitation crab, leaving 1 inch of rice from the bottom.
(7) Roll the mat over, keeping the filling in place with your fingers, so that you make a tight log!
(8) Remove the rolling mat, and (grown ups!) use a sharp, wet knife to slice into pieces.
-
TIPS
• PREP THE MATERIALS: Having the items prepped will make the process run so much smoother.
-
• STICKY SOLUTION: The very nature of sushi rice is that it is sticky! Have plenty of dish towels and a bowl of water nearby to reset clean hands!
-
• SLICING THE SUSHI: My 3yo tried slicing the sushi with his kid-friendly knife, but it was not sharp enough to do the job! So have a grown-up do this part!
-

node.text:
If you have a picky eater (or as I like to say, a selective eater), then you know introducing new or different foods can be a challenge! 😅 But, oh. my. gosh! 😍 Here is an activity, that brought the fun back to our kitchen table! 🤩 We approached this experiment-style, noting exposure to a new food through sight, feel, and ultimately taste! 👅 I gave my selective eater 4 new foods to explore —  @gimmegrams seaweed, kiwi, pan de yuca, and sautéed carrots — and his exploration of each was absolutely amazing! 🙌 I’d love to know whether you’ll try this too! Or if you know a friend who this activity might benefit, be sure to share it with them! 👌 Any questions at all? Drop👇 them in the comment section below, or DM me!
-
#gimmepartner #gimmeseaweed
-

node.text:
This diy counting board is the perfect tactile resource for early math learning! 🤩 The removable cards and moveable wooden beads are perfect for some hands on fun. 🙌 While this craft certainly takes a little more effort to create than most of our activities, the good news is, it is a resource we come back to time and time again! 👌 Plus, it is super adaptable for children at different math levels as you can add as many beads as you like! 👍 Read on below👇for the how-to and if you have any questions at all, send me a direct message!
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
• 2 pieces of identical Cardboard, and additional cardboard for number cards
• Twine or thick string
• Beads
• Glue
• Hole punch
-
HOW TO
(1) Using a sharp knife, cut out 2 rectangular shapes on one of the cardboard pieces. This is where the number cards will go.
(2) Then cut out a thin, long rectangle below. This is where the tactile counting beads will go.
(3) Punch a hole on each end of the rectangle;
(4) Tie a piece of twine through one hole securely;
(5) Thread the beads onto the twine and secure the beads by tying the other end to the hole;
(6) Glue the 2 cardboard pieces together, with the beads and cut out pieces on the top;
(7) Take scrap cardboard, and cut out rectangle shapes for the number cards;
(8) On each rectangle, write each number. If counting to 20, you’ll need two 1s. If counting to 30, you’ll need an additional two 2s, and so forth. Now the board is ready for some serious counting fun!
-

node.text:
Discover the beautiful colors of the Autumn season with this fun arts and crafts project! 🍁 #ad It’s all about crafting a fall leaf, 🍂 then disguising it as a green leaf, 🍃only to discover it scratch-off style! 🤩 We used supplies from the @michaelsstores Creatology collection - their oil pastels had the perfect vibrant and seasonal tones this project needed! 🎨 Plus, their coverups kept my kiddos' clothes clean while they used the bright green acrylic paint! 😅 Highly recommend stopping by Michaels whenever you are in need of kids craft supplies! Need step-by-step instructions on how to create this project too? Read on below👇 for all the details and don’t forget to save this post for later so you remember to do it too! Oh, and if you need a leaf template, head to my link in bio for our free printable! 👌 
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
• Our Free Fall Leaf Template
• Mixed Media or Watercolor Paper
• Oil Pastels
• Green Acrylic Paint
• Paint Brushes
• Coin
-
HOW TO
(1) Print out an Autumn leaf (free printable available at 7daysofplay.com)
(2) Use oil pastels to color the leaf in Autumn colors - like brown, orange, and red!
(3) Cover the leaf with green acrylic paint
(4) Once dried, use a coin to scratch way the green paint to reveal an Autumn leaf!
-
#MakeItWithMichaels
-
#fallcraft #kidscrafts #kidsactivities #kids #kidsart #diy #creativekids #montessori #learningthroughplay #crafts #preschool #earlylearning #kidsofinstagram #kidscraft #preschoolactivities #craft #craftsforkids #homeschool #toddleractivities #sensoryplay #kindergarten #activitiesforkids #playbasedlearning #kidscraftideas #kidsfashion #montessoriathome #artsandcrafts

node.text:
Who else is going to start saving their bean water? 🙋‍♀️ It really makes the perfect sensory foam that even babies and toddlers can play with safely! 🙌Throw in a little orange coloring and even some cinnamon along with some fallen leaves and pine cones and it makes for such a fun Fall-themed sensory bin! 🍂 Read on below 👇 for the easy recipe, and don’t forget to save this post so you remember to do it later!
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
• 1 Can Chickpeas
• Orange food coloring
• Cinnamon (optional)
• Fall items (leaves, sticks, apple, pine cones)
• Sensory Bowl and Tool Set
-
(1) To make the taste-safe foam, pour the chickpea water into a bowl and save the chickpeas for a yummy lunch or dinner!
-
(2) Whip the chickpea water for 5 minutes until it forms a thick, creamy foam. 
-
(3) Then, add in orange food coloring and cinnamon for a fall-themed scent and look!
-
(4) Add some bowls and spoons for scooping and transferring fall-themed items like leaves, sticks, apples, and pine cones.
-

node.text:
We made Taste-Safe Sand to inspire baby girl to dive into all things construction! 🏗 Her adorable dress is from @piccolina_kids’ Discovery Collection, which is all about showcasing empowering themes from construction to paleontology to robotics and beyond! 😍 We definitely believe that playtime can inspire passion and what better way to explore all things construction than to dig your hands into some super fun sensory play! 🚧 Read on below 👇 for the how-to directions on this taste-safe recipe that even babies can enjoy playing with! And don’t forget to save this post so you remember to do it later!
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
• 2 cups Stale Cereal (or toasted flour - remember flour is considered raw until cooked!).
• 2 cups corn stach
• 2/3 cup cooking oil
-
HOW TO
(1) Blend stale cereal until it is like powder. You could also use fresh cereal, but why not make use of the stale stuff first?!
(2) Mix in 2 cups corn starch and 2/3 cup cooking oil.
(3) Mix until it is the texture of wet sand - crumbly yet moldable!
(4) Add construction vehicles and loose parts like rocks for a fun construction-themed activity!
-
PLUS, you can explore Piccolina’s Discovery Collection at the link in my bio! Use code MICHELLE20 at checkout for 20% off your order.
-

node.text:
Can you believe this adorable art project is made up of nature materials we found out in our yard?! 😍 I love how this activity not only allows kids to enjoy the outdoors and explore the world around them, 🌳 but also shows them they don't have to have fancy toys or electronics to have a good time! 🤗 Read on below👇 for more details on how we transformed these nature items into a fun art project, and save this post so you remember to do it later! 💕
-
My kiddos wanted to create zebras, painting the sticks and rocks white and black, as well as some yellow for a sun, and then adding some grass for some texture! I helped them arrange everything and added the final details with a black permanent marker.
-
My kiddo’s favorite part? Whittling sticks to make the paint go on easier! Of course, supervision is key and use your best judgment on when you think your kiddo is ready to use a peeler!
-

node.text:
Pun very much so intended!! 🤣 We are a barefoot family (well, me and my kids are!). Ripping off their shoes is the first thing they do when they get in the car after being picked up from school. 💨👟From their sole to their soul, there are lots of benefits for safely going barefoot. (Safety is key here! I would NEVER allow my kids to go stampeding in an area that could hurt them or make them sick! 🙅‍♀️). Going barefoot strengthens the feet and leg muscles, promotes body awareness, benefits balance, and provides a ton of sensory learning (wet, dry, cold, hot, sandy, muddy - so many textures to experience and understand). 🙌 Plus, you may have heard people talk about the benefits of Earthing or Grounding which is all about allowing our skin to directly touch the surface of the Earth to absorb Earth’s electrons and balance us out. 🧘‍♀️ I don’t know so much about the science of all that and whether it can really reduce inflammation, help you sleep better, reduce pain, and stress, etc. But what I do know is I’ll never be the mom at the playground who gasps and says “put your shoes back on!” 😅Nope. I’ll be watching them climb those trees 🌳 more efficiently, wrap their toes to balance more steadily,🦶and run with a deeper understanding of what is beneath them! 😍
-
Share this with a friend who needs to see this too!
-

node.text:
You can swap out for water, 💦 but paint 🎨 is so much fun! This is truly such a great way to create process art while strengthening fine motor skills. 🙌 Head to my link in bio for all the details  including what spray bottles we have and tips on making the most of this activity! 👌 Don’t forget to save this post so you remember to do it later, and share it with a friend who may want to do it too! 💕
-

node.text:
🚗 This DIY car toy is a genius way to use recycled materials for a craft you can play with! ♻️ It also makes for a fun storage solution! 🙌 Read on below👇 for the simple steps on how you can make one too! And don’t forget to save this post for later so you remember to do it! 💕
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
Paper Tubes
Hot Glue or Tacky Glue
Paint Sticks
Branches
Toy Cars
-
HOW TO
(1) Assemble the paper tubes in a triangle shape. We started with 5 at the base, and decreased by one with each layer. To stick them together quickly, use hot glue, but if you prefer the kiddo's to do on their own, then use tacky glue.
-
(2) Glue 4 toilet paper tubes at the base for a raised look. This also allows cars to ride and park underneath!
-
(3) Add 4 paper tube rolls on the roof sides. These make for fun ramps!
-
(4) Optional, add sticks to the roof or other items as details!
-
(5) Finally, have the kids color the paper tubes and sticks. If you use paint sticks, it will dry very quickly!
-
#kidsart #kidsartwork #kidscraft #kidscrafts #kidcrafts #craftingwithkids #playandlearn #toddlerart  #preschoolart #artteachers #makeandcreate #montessoriart #kidscraft101 #everydayplayhacks  #artwithkids #craftymom #craftymommy #creativechildhood #funcraftskids #preschoolcrafts #preschoolart #activitiesforkids #kids #kidsactivities #activities #activitiesfortoddlers #fun #learningthroughplay #learning #education

node.text:
This insect play dough kit is a great way for kids to get hands on while learning all about bugs!  🐛 We love themed play dough kits - they are such an awesome way for sensory and imaginative play to collide. 😍 Read on below👇 for our homemade play dough recipe. And head to my link in bio for more info on how to assemble a kit like this and to extend the insect learning with our insect-themed printable worksheets! 🐜 
-
Don’t forget to save this post for the next time you need to grab this play dough recipe! 👇
-
NO COOK PLAY DOUGH RECIPE
Mix Together
• 1 1/4 cup of all-purpose flour
• 1/3 cup of fine salt
• 2 tablespoon of cream of tartar
• 2 tablespoon coconut oil (optional)
Add
• 3/4 cup of boiling water (I mix in food coloring to water prior to heating water up in microwave).
• I wear gloves and mix the *very hot* play dough by hand to make sure that the dough is kneaded thoroughly, which spreads the heat, dissolving the granules to make a smooth texture.
Note
*If too sticky add a little more flour
*If too dry add a little more water
*Coconut Oil gives the play dough a super silky texture. You could also use glycerine. Alternatively, other vegetable oil will work too, but I’ve found that coconut oil makes it super silky!
*Cream of Tartar is a preservative, it makes the play dough have a longer shelf life.
-
